awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Polymer Sponge Electrodes for Energy-Efficient Desalination
awd_abstract_narration:
Current seawater desalination technology is energy-intensive and costly, limiting our ability to generate clean water for an increasing global population. In recent years, researchers have explored a new concept based on the removal of salt from seawater using a battery-like device where salt water flows into the device, salt ions bind to electrodes within the device, and fresh water flows out. One would expect this technology, called capacitive deionization (CDI), to maximize the energy efficiency of desalination by recovering input energy through discharge of the electrodes—similar to charging and discharging a battery. However, the performance of CDI devices has not yet been competitive for seawater desalination. Researchers at the University of Missouri will work to understand the origins of the poor performance of CDI electrodes for seawater desalination and overcome these limitations to boost the energy efficiency of CDI. The investigators will decouple and independently study the two main factors thought to drive CDI inefficiency – low ion uptake capacity and slow ion transport within CDI electrodes. Electrically conductive coatings that bind large amounts of ions will be used to control the ion uptake capacity of electrodes, while a soft, compressible electrode matrix will be used to control the rate of ion transport within the electrodes using mechanical compression during charging. This work will fill a critical gap in understanding how electrode design aspects are coupled with physical processes to drive CDI performance. The outcomes of this project will define the most promising avenues for investigation in pursuit of the next generation of desalination technology.

This project will establish a new modality of CDI electrode that integrates high-rate, faradaic surface reactions for rapid ion uptake within a soft, compressible sponge substrate for rapid ion transport within the CDI electrode through mechanical compression of the sponge. To generate these electrodes, researchers will employ established molecular layer deposition (MLD) chemistry using sequential reaction of gas-phase precursors to impregnate microporous polyurethane (PU) foams with electrically-conductive and redox-active polyethylenedioxythiophene (PEDOT) coatings. The project will (1) study key synthesis aspects enabling the fabrication of compressible CDI electrodes and (2) benchmark what level of CDI efficiency can be delivered from compressible electrodes. Researchers will study the impact of PEDOT thickness, foam void volume, and compression rate on the energy efficiency of ion uptake. This work will help researchers understand and overcome the barriers limiting the performance of existing CDI electrodes, potentially enabling CDI to outperform current seawater desalination technology and providing low-cost, clean water to help address global water scarcity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Curators of the University of Missouri

por.por_cntn:
Current seawater desalination technology is energy intensive and costly, limiting our ability to use this technology to generate clean water for an increasing global population. In recent years, researchers have explored a new concept based on the removal of salt from seawater using a device like a battery where salt water flows into the device, salt ions bind to electrodes within the device, and fresh water flows out. In its simplest form, this technology is called capacitive deionization, or CDI, and would seem to be able to maximize the energy efficiency of desalination by recovering input energy through discharge of the electrodes—similar to charging and discharging a battery. But, to date, the performance of CDI devices has not been competitive for seawater desalination. In this project, researchers at the University of Missouri worked to understand the origins of the poor performance of CDI electrodes for seawater desalination. Specifically, researchers worked to decouple and independently study the two main factors thought to drive CDI inefficiency – low ion uptake capacity and slow ion transport within CDI electrodes.  Electrically conductive coatings that bind large amounts of ions were studied to control ion uptake capacity of electrodes, while the infiltration of these coatings within a soft, compressible electrode matrix was examined to control the rate of ion transport within the electrodes using mechanical compression during charging. Key outcomes from this project included (i) understanding how the thickness of conductive polymer films influences orientation of polymer domains and slows ion diffusion, (ii) demonstration of methods to convert insulating sponge foams into conductive, compressible foam electrodes through vapor deposition of conductive polymers within 3D open-cell foams, (iii) employing a theoretical computational framework to understand how thickness and pore diameter drive diffusion limitations in porous electrodes, and (iv) discovery of the ability to control the molecular sequence of conductive polymers to produce unexpectedly high ion uptake capacity.  This project also supported preliminary work to (v) construct an electro-mechanical test stand to measure the ion-uptake properties of sponge electrodes under mechanical compression, and (vi) to synthesize high-capacity carbon nanotube (CNT) forest electrodes by depositing conductive polymers within CNT forests through vapor deposition.

The rational control of the electrical properties of porous material established in this work is relevant to nanomanufacturing, the engineering and design of biomedical sensors, and fundamental electrochemistry. The innovations in this area afforded by this project are expected to impact the field of gas-phase synthesis of composite nanostructures by providing guiding principles and insights to impart electrically conductivity on porous substrates. Additionally, the molecular scale control over the molecular sequence of conjugated redox-active polymers enabled by this award is expected to enable the study of previously intractable questions regarding the molecular origins of electronic and ionic transport in conductive polymers. This has implications for fundamental polymer physics and materials science, chemical engineering, and electrical engineering disciplines, and will help these disciplines further the fundamental understanding relevant to the design and fabrication of electrochemical devices in general. Finally, the compressible electrode test cell will enable the study of the electro-mechanical properties of compressible electrodes and help understand what benefits might be afforded on electrochemical systems using mechanical compression. In total, this project resulted in the publication of four peer-reviewed publications, eleven conference presentations, and one patent.

In addition to the scholarly impacts, this project contributed to the professional development of three PhD graduate students, and four undergraduate students. The project also helped support the students on the project to participate in outreach activities with the University of Missouri Engineers’ Week, where >500 elementary to high school students from throughout Missouri participated in open-house activities, and compressible sponge electrodes were used to demonstrate principles of materials science and nanomanufacturing.

 


Last Modified: 12/26/2024
Modified by: Matthias J Young

por.por_txt_cntn:
Current seawater desalination technology is energy intensive and costly, limiting our ability to use this technology to generate clean water for an increasing global population. In recent years, researchers have explored a new concept based on the removal of salt from seawater using a device like a battery where salt water flows into the device, salt ions bind to electrodes within the device, and fresh water flows out. In its simplest form, this technology is called capacitive deionization, or CDI, and would seem to be able to maximize the energy efficiency of desalination by recovering input energy through discharge of the electrodessimilar to charging and discharging a battery. But, to date, the performance of CDI devices has not been competitive for seawater desalination. In this project, researchers at the University of Missouri worked to understand the origins of the poor performance of CDI electrodes for seawater desalination. Specifically, researchers worked to decouple and independently study the two main factors thought to drive CDI inefficiency  low ion uptake capacity and slow ion transport within CDI electrodes. Electrically conductive coatings that bind large amounts of ions were studied to control ion uptake capacity of electrodes, while the infiltration of these coatings within a soft, compressible electrode matrix was examined to control the rate of ion transport within the electrodes using mechanical compression during charging. Key outcomes from this project included (i) understanding how the thickness of conductive polymer films influences orientation of polymer domains and slows ion diffusion, (ii) demonstration of methods to convert insulating sponge foams into conductive, compressible foam electrodes through vapor deposition of conductive polymers within 3D open-cell foams, (iii) employing a theoretical computational framework to understand how thickness and pore diameter drive diffusion limitations in porous electrodes, and (iv) discovery of the ability to control the molecular sequence of conductive polymers to produce unexpectedly high ion uptake capacity. This project also supported preliminary work to (v) construct an electro-mechanical test stand to measure the ion-uptake properties of sponge electrodes under mechanical compression, and (vi) to synthesize high-capacity carbon nanotube (CNT) forest electrodes by depositing conductive polymers within CNT forests through vapor deposition.


The rational control of the electrical properties of porous material established in this work is relevant to nanomanufacturing, the engineering and design of biomedical sensors, and fundamental electrochemistry. The innovations in this area afforded by this project are expected to impact the field of gas-phase synthesis of composite nanostructures by providing guiding principles and insights to impart electrically conductivity on porous substrates. Additionally, the molecular scale control over the molecular sequence of conjugated redox-active polymers enabled by this award is expected to enable the study of previously intractable questions regarding the molecular origins of electronic and ionic transport in conductive polymers. This has implications for fundamental polymer physics and materials science, chemical engineering, and electrical engineering disciplines, and will help these disciplines further the fundamental understanding relevant to the design and fabrication of electrochemical devices in general. In total, this project resulted in the publication of four peer-reviewed publications, eleven conference presentations, and one patent.


In addition to the scholarly impacts, this project contributed to the professional development of three PhD graduate students, and four undergraduate students. The project also helped support the students on the project to participate in outreach activities with the University of Missouri Engineers Week, where 500 elementary to high school students from throughout Missouri participated in open-house activities, and compressible sponge electrodes were used to demonstrate principles of materials science and nanomanufacturing.
